So EAF stands for EVM object format and is kind of our idea to structure the EVM programs
in the way that they kind of behave more predictable way.
So we know where the data is in the program, we know the code is, and we can version program.
So that also gives us some additional backwards compatibility features.
And on top of that, we can build additional features.
And these three additional features are the next three EAPs on the list.
So firstly, EAF allows us to define instructions in a bit different way.
So we can have some immediate values, means the opcode can be followed by additional numbers.
That means something to the instruction that will interpret it, that will interpret the
values following.
That wasn't possible before because of the backwards compatibility of existing EVM.
So you can, in the current EVM, you can craft a program that will break if you interpret
values following opcodes in a different way.
So these static jumps are more efficient than current ones.
And also, this is also easier to analyze from external tools and also from the code validation
in the EVM itself.
And additionally, the next one is EOF functions, which means we can additionally partition the
EVM code into separate sections, meaning individual native functions in the EVM.
And there are additional instructions that allows you to go between these partitions.
And all combined with the static jumps and the functions, we can get rid of existing dynamic
jumps in the EVM, which it should improve efficiency and most importantly, we can get
rid of jump this analysis.
So the jump this analysis is a process that has to be performed before we can start even
executing EVM programs currently.
And it's like the cost of doing that is proportional to the size of the code and none of the cost
of EVM execution actually reflects this analysis.
And lastly, we can also put additional verification in the EOF format that will allow you to check
statically before deploying the code.
If a function performs stack overflow or possibly stack underflow and we can reject such
programs, such programs would be by definition a bit more restrictive than the current ones.
So there are some tricks you can do in current EVM that would not be possible anymore, but
I think most of the compilers that target EVM doesn't really exploit this, exploit this
properties.
So that also brings some additional efficiencies because you can kind of check for correctness
at least in the terms of stack behavior during deploy time and you don't have to repeat this
checks later during execution.
